title: Significant Chemical/HazMat Spill
description: A hazardous chemical container has ruptured in an industrial facility, releasing corrosive liquid across the floor as emergency responders in full PPE deploy absorbent barriers to contain the spread. Workers evacuate through marked routes while the incident commander activates the emergency eyewash station for an exposed employee. The critical window for containment, decontamination protocols, and coordinated evacuation determines whether this remains a localized incident or escalates into a facility-wide emergency.
stats:
• 190,000+ chemical incidents annually in US
• 30,000+ injuries per year
• $500M+ in damages
• Manufacturing/labs highest risk
• 60% occur due to human error
scoringDimensions: Containment Speed, Evacuation Safety, PPE Adherence

title: Gas Leak Response
description: A gas detector alarm is sounding with a warning light flashing. You need to open windows and doors for ventilation, turn off the gas valve at the meter, and calmly evacuate the building while calling emergency services.
stats:
• 300+ deaths annually from gas leaks
• 15,000+ injuries per year
• $100M+ property damage
• Natural gas/propane most common
• 80% preventable with proper response

title: Cardiac Arrest
description: A 55-year-old male has collapsed in a crowded shopping mall. He is unconscious, with shallow breathing and a weak pulse. Immediate action is required. You must initiate CPR, prepare and use the Automated External Defibrillator (AED), and manage the crowd while calling for help.

stats.common_info: Crowded area, multiple witnesses, AED available nearby.

scoringDimensions: CPR Quality, AED Application Speed, Crowd Management

title: Fire Emergency Response
description: Flames and smoke are spreading in an office. You must use a fire extinguisher following the PASS method, pull the fire alarm, and guide people to evacuate through a marked exit as smoke detectors activate.
stats:
• 3,340 workplace fires daily
• 200+ deaths, 5,000+ injuries yearly
• $2.3B annual damage
• Leading cause: electrical (23%)
• OSHA requires evacuation training
scoringDimensions: Alarm Activation Speed, Extinguisher Use, Evacuation Path

title: Electrical Hazard Response
description: At a construction site, an electrical panel is sparking, creating an arc flash hazard. You must use insulated tools and wear appropriate PPE (rubber gloves, face shield) to switch off the circuit breaker and apply lockout/tagout devices.
stats:
• 300+ electrocution deaths annually
• 4,000+ non-fatal injuries
• #5 cause of workplace deaths
• Construction industry: 52% of deaths
• 80% involve power lines/equipment
scoringDimensions: Power Deactivation, PPE Usage, Hazard Isolation
